Document.TEXT:
Special relationship." The phrase sounds innocuous enough, even heartwarming. For those who have been sexually abused by priests, it's infuriating. "Special relationship" is a phrase pedophile clergymen often use with victims, trying to convince them that molestation is some kind of holy secret that must never be disclosed. "That's what the perpetrators almost universally call it," says David Clohessy, the national director of the Survivors Network of Those Abused by Priests (SNAP) and himself a victim of abuse. "If you get a group of survivors together and say that phrase, everyone will groan."
The problem of pedophilia among priests, long dismissed by the Catholic hierarchy, has begun to take on crisis proportions for the church. Each week brings new revelations not only of molestation, but also of alleged cover-ups. On March 8, for instance, Anthony O'Connell, the bishop of the Catholic diocese of Palm Beach, resigned in disgrace after reports that he had molested a teenage boy at a seminary more than 25 years ago surfaced in newspapers. In another, potentially even more damaging case, The Hartford Courant dug out sealed court papers showing that while serving as the bishop of Bridgeport, Conn., in the '90s, Edward Cardinal Egan, now the head of the New York archdiocese, allowed priests accused of molestation to continue working—all the while downplaying that there was any problem. In a statement, though, on March 19, Egan forcefully denounced molestation as an "abomination."
As it is, the church is facing enormous legal and financial trouble as a result of a flood of lawsuits from those claiming to be victims. In Boston alone the archdiocese has already paid out as much as $30 million to settle more than 80 suits—and could end up paying out $100 million or more to cover all the claims. The allegations center on John Geoghan, the defrocked priest who may have molested 130 children and was sentenced last month to 9 to 10 years in prison for abusing a 10-year-old boy, as well as on disclosures that Bernard Cardinal Law turned a blind eye to the allegations. As critics see it, now is the time, at long last, for the church to embrace candor. "They should tell the truth, plain and simple," says the Rev. Gary Hayes, a Catholic priest in Kentucky, who says that as a youth he himself was molested by clergymen. "Get it out in the open."
It is a situation that David Clohessy, 45, understands well. For the past decade, in his work for the Chicago-based SNAP, he has counseled victims by phone and e-mail; so far, more than 3,000 Catholics claiming abuse at the hands of priests have joined the organization. But Clohessy, who is also director of community services for a St. Louis school district, has no doubt that the number of youngsters molested over the years is far higher—and the damage done far greater—than anyone can yet imagine. "I keep thinking of all the pain," he says. "It was so preventable. This wasn't a chemical that we all thought was okay and only recently discovered was toxic. We knew. [The church] knew. It could've been stopped."
As Clohessy's own experience suggests, though, rooting out the predators is not always easy. The second of six children, he grew up in Moberly, Mo., where his father, Joseph, a retired claims agent, and mother Mary, a homemaker, were actively involved in the neighborhood parish, St. Pius X. "My dad was in the Knights of Columbus," says Clohessy. "My mom served on the church decorating committees." It was a great source of family pride that one of their closest friends was the then-associate pastor at St. Pius, Father John Whiteley.
According to David, by the time he was 11 or so, Whiteley had begun to take a particular interest in him. He was made an altar boy, and Whiteley invited him to the rectory to help with various tasks. Nothing untoward happened. Then, one time, during a visit to the Clohessy home, Whiteley playfully grabbed David and tickled him. It made David feel slightly uncomfortable, but he now believes there was an ulterior motive. "It's clear now he was testing my assertiveness," says Clohessy. "How would I respond to this?" There followed weekend camping trips, then longer excursions, just Whiteley and David together, to Florida, Colorado and the East Coast, for vacations. His parents never questioned the relationship. "It sounds weird now, but you have to understand what a huge honor it was then," says David, "to think a priest was taking an interest in you or your son."
It was during the trips, says David, that Whiteley began to touch him sexually. The abuse stretched over four years. During that time David tried to pretend that nothing had happened. He simply put the incidents out of his mind. Finally, one night at age 15, while on a trip with Whiteley, David awoke in a hotel bed to find the priest fondling him. "I said, 'Stop, I don't want you to do that,' " recalls David. "And he stopped." Indeed Whiteley never attempted to molest him again. From then on the two maintained a friendship, even when David went off to Drury College in Springfield, Mo. "I blocked it out because it was incredible to think that a priest would touch me sexually," says David. "No one talked about sex."
Other priests took more elaborate steps to manipulate their victims and coerce them into silence. As detailed in a lawsuit, Father Hayes, now 49, says his local pastor, Rev. Joseph McGarvey, began plying him with alcohol at age 14. "It wasn't unusual to get drunk at the rectory a couple of nights a week," says Hayes, who grew up in Millville, N.J., always wanting to be a priest. Then came the pornographic movies and magazines. McGarvey was building complicity, making it tougher for Hayes to tattle on him to his parents. After about six months of softening up, Hayes says, McGarvey started molesting him. When he tried to protest, McGarvey simply made him feel as though he were the one behaving inappropriately. "He'd get really pissed off and tell me he's just trying to be a good friend," says Hayes. "I always had the sense that I was letting him down if I didn't go along with everything he wanted."
The worst of it is, the abused are certain that they are all alone. For Don Hoard Jr. it meant telling his parents what a good time he had at age 11 at a Catholic Youth Organization camp in Leggett, Calif.—and not telling them that he had been molested by the camp director, Rev. Gary Timmons. "The last thing you want to do is tell anyone," says Hoard, 39, an accountant who lives with his wife, Cindy, and their three children in Windsor, Calif. "Every survivor I've met assumes they're the only one."
In the years after the abuse, survivors agree, the crushing sense of isolation builds. It is not true that every victim takes to drink or drugs or winds up in one broken relationship after another, although many do. What is true is that the experience changes the life of the victim in some profound way. Hoard coped by forcing himself to become a high achiever. "I felt so disgusted and tainted," he says. "I wanted to prove I was perfect." It didn't work. "I was high school valedictorian and went to Berkeley," says Hoard. "But I never felt good about any of that stuff." (Accused of abusing more than a dozen youngsters, Timmons eventually pleaded guilty to molestation and was sentenced to eight years in prison.) Hoard drew support from his father, Don Sr., who encouraged him to come forward and has himself become an activist on behalf of those molested.
For David Clohessy it has helped that his wife, Laura Barrett, 41, is a social worker. Even so, his life has been marked by a constant wariness and unease that something terrible was about to befall him. "I've always been distrustful of authority figures, especially males," says Clohessy, who has two young sons. "If a male boss compliments me, I think, 'What's next?' " For many victims, one way out of the depression that can plague them is to fight back against their tormenters. Clohessy awoke, in a sense, to the realization of what had happened to him in the late '80s, when he happened to see the movie Nuts, with Barbra Streisand, which involved recovered memories. "I never thought I'd been abused," says Clohessy. "[Then] it all came back to me."
One of his first steps was to tell his parents and other members of his family. It was a relief that even though they were shocked, they immediately believed him. "I knew that during that call he was going through the abuse all over again," says his brother Patrick, 37, the manager for an insurance company in Wisconsin. "It was painful, very painful." David had one brief meeting with Whiteley. "It was clear to me his goal was to assure me he'd taken care of his problem," says Clohessy.
Even so, Clohessy's depression was deepening. During one period he didn't leave the house for two months. In August 1991 he filed a suit against Whiteley, the church and the diocese. It turned out, however, that—as in so many of these abuse cases—the statute of limitations had lapsed. Nevertheless the diocese launched its own investigation of Whiteley, who agreed to resign his position in the church. (Whiteley did not respond to requests for an interview.) In 1993 Father Hayes filed his own suit against McGarvey. It was settled without the priest, who quickly retired, admitting any wrongdoing.
But challenging the church can be fraught with difficulties, as Joseph Elliott discovered. In 1999 Elliott, now 43, a hairdresser in Portland, Ore., filed a suit against his former priest Maurice Grammond, alleging that Grammond had molested him when he was an 11-year-old altar boy. The Portland archdiocese indignantly denied the charge, and some in the local media questioned Elliott's motives. But Elliott had a plan. He says he phoned Grammond, who was then 79 and suffering from Alzheimer's, and tape recorded the priest testily dismissing the whole scandal by saying that Elliott had merely been "looking for excitement." Eventually, more than 20 other plaintiffs joined Elliott's suit, which was settled for an undisclosed sum in 2000. "The shame is not ours anymore," says Elliott. "It belongs to the perpetrators and the people who allowed them to do that."
But the sadness remains, especially for those who feel they have been driven from the church they once loved. Three of Maryetta Dussourd's sons were molested by John Geoghan. The 57-year-old Boston clerk still reads her Bible daily, always carries a rosary and wears two religious medallions around her neck-but she no longer attends services because being inside a church makes her too upset. "I can't control my emotions," says Dussourd. "The tears just start flowing, and I can't stop them." Against the backdrop of his own experience and the torrent of distressing news reports, David Clohessy tries to maintain some perspective, not to mention hope. "Maybe justice isn't always-or usually-possible, but healing is," he says. "But only if you talk about it."
Bill Hewitt Kate Klise in St. Louis, Lauren Comander in Chicago, Melissa Schorr in Santa Rosa, Calif., Alexandra Hardy in Portland, Tom Duffy in Boston and Diane Herbst in Margate, N.J.
